src:
Kasus DBD Meningkat Hampir 100 Persen, Jawa Barat Paling Parah
05 Nov 2019, 05:50 by Yusuf Wijanarko
JAKARTA, (PR).- Kementerian Kesehatan mencatat, terdapat 110.921 kasus DBD (demam berdarah dengue) di Indonesia pada periode Januari hingga 31 Oktober 2019.
"Angka ini meningkat cukup drastis dari 2018 dengan jumlah kasus berada dia angka 65.602 kasus," kata Direktur Pencegahan dan Pengendalian Penyakit Tular Vektor dan Zoonotik Siti Nadia Tarmizi di Jakarta, Selasa 5 November 2019.
Dia menjelaskan, peningkatan kasus DBD pada 2019 salah satunya disebabkan beberapa kabupaten dan kota di Indonesia mengalami kejadian luar biasa (KLB).
Selain itu, masih banyak masyarakat yang tidak melakukan pemberantasan sarang nyamuk (PSN) secara rutin. Misalnya, mengumpulkan dan membersihkan botol-botol minuman yang bisa menjadi sarang nyamuk.
Kabupaten dan kota yang mengalami KLB DBD tersebut di antaranya Kota Manado, Kota Kupang, dan Labuan Bajo.



Secara rinci, dia menyebut, kasus DBD tertinggi per 31 Oktober 2019 ditemukan di Jawa Barat dengan total 19.240 kasus.
Posisi kedua dihuni Jawa Timur dengan 16.699 kasus, Jawa Tengah 8.501 kasus, Jakarta 8.408 kasus, Sumatra Utara 5.721 kasus, dan Lampung 5.369 kasus.
"Secara keseluruhan kasus terbanyak ditemukan di Jawa dan Bali dengan total 61.071 kasus. Kemudian Sumatra sebanyak 21.896 kasus," kata dia sperti diberitakan Antara.
Tidak merata
Tingginya angka DBD di Indonesia tidak berarti semua daerah terdampak. Masih ada beberapa daerah yang berada pada zona hijau dengan angka DBD rendah.
Daerah-daerah yang tergolong aman tersebut di antaranya adalah Papua Barat dengan angka DBD terendah yakni 49 kasus, Papua 132 kasus, Maluku 245 kasus, Sulawesi Barat 559 kasus, dan Bangka Belitung 632 kasus.
Selain itu, Jambi, Bengkulu, Kalimantan Tengah, Kalimantan Utara, Nusa Tenggara Timur, Nusa Tenggara Barat, Gorontalo, dan Sulawesi Tenggara juga berada pada zona hijau dengan angka temuan DBD di bawah 1.400 kasus.
berdasarkan usia, temuan kasus DBD di berbagai daerah didominasi warga usia 5-14 tahun atau 43,25 persen dari keseluruhan kasus.
Selanjutnya usia 15-44 tahun sebanyak 36,46 persen, di atas 44 tahun 9,68 persen, usia 1-4 tahun 8,54 kasus dan terendah pada usia di bawah 1 tahun 2,07 persen.***

Baca Juga
text:
DBD Case Increases Nearly 100 Percent, West Java is the Most Severe
05 Nov 2019, 05:50 by Yusuf Wijanarko
JAKARTA, (PR) .- The Ministry of Health noted that there were 110,921 cases of DHF (dengue hemorrhagic fever) in Indonesia in the period from January to 31 October 2019.
"This number has increased quite dramatically from 2018 with the number being 65,602 cases," said Director of the Prevention and Control of Vector and Zoonotic Diseases Siti Nadia Tarmizi in Jakarta, Tuesday, November 5, 2019.
He explained, the increase in dengue cases in 2019 was partly due to several districts and cities in Indonesia experiencing extraordinary events (KLB).
In addition, there are still many people who do not eradicate mosquito nests (PSN) regularly. For example, collecting and cleaning drink bottles that can become mosquito breeding grounds.
Regencies and cities that have experienced outbreaks include the City of Manado, Kupang City, and Labuan Bajo.



In detail, he said, the highest DHF cases as of October 31, 2019 were found in West Java with a total of 19,240 cases.
The second position is occupied by East Java with 16,699 cases, Central Java 8,501 cases, Jakarta 8,408 cases, North Sumatra 5,721 cases, and Lampung 5,369 cases.
"Overall, the most cases were found in Java and Bali with a total of 61,071 cases. Then Sumatra totaled 21,896 cases," he said as reported by Antara.
Uneven
The high number of DHF in Indonesia does not mean that all regions are affected. There are still some areas that are in the green zone with low DHF numbers.
The areas classified as safe include West Papua with the lowest number of DHF, 49 cases, Papua 132 cases, Maluku 245 cases, West Sulawesi 559 cases, and Bangka Belitung 632 cases.
In addition, Jambi, Bengkulu, Central Kalimantan, North Kalimantan, East Nusa Tenggara, West Nusa Tenggara, Gorontalo and Southeast Sulawesi are also in the green zone with DHF findings below 1,400 cases.
by age, DHF case findings in various regions were dominated by residents aged 5-14 years or 43.25 percent of all cases.
Furthermore, aged 15-44 years as much as 36.46 percent, above 44 years 9.68 percent, ages 1-4 years 8.54 cases and the lowest at ages under 1 year 2.07 percent. ***
